episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:07.379
[SOUND] Welcome to your EC-Council
Certified Encryption Specialist series.

2
00:00:07.379 --> 00:00:10.949
Whether you're looking to take the exam or
just brush up on your skill set,

3
00:00:10.949 --> 00:00:12.980
this is the perfect place for you.

4
00:00:12.980 --> 00:00:16.280
With us, we have Mr. Adam Gordon
in studios to cover this topic.

5
00:00:16.280 --> 00:00:17.980
Thank you for joining us today, Adam.

6
00:00:17.980 --> 00:00:18.700
>> Thank you.

7
00:00:18.700 --> 00:00:21.593
Always a pleasure to be here at
ITPRO.TV and spend time with you and

8
00:00:21.593 --> 00:00:24.160
with our wonderful co-hosts,
like Cherokee.

9
00:00:24.160 --> 00:00:27.640
And talking about encryption
in particular is so exciting.

10
00:00:27.640 --> 00:00:29.012
It's so relevant to what we do today.

11
00:00:29.012 --> 00:00:33.038
We're gonna be taking you on a journey,
helping you to better understand things,

12
00:00:33.038 --> 00:00:37.110
like what is the difference between
symmetric and asymmetric cryptography?

13
00:00:37.110 --> 00:00:39.490
What are digital signatures and hashes?

14
00:00:39.490 --> 00:00:40.190
How do they work?

15
00:00:40.190 --> 00:00:41.330
Why are they important?

16
00:00:41.330 --> 00:00:42.804
We'll throw a little history and

17
00:00:42.804 --> 00:00:45.445
background into the mix there
on cryptography in general.

18
00:00:45.445 --> 00:00:48.076
Look backwards,
see what people years, hundreds,

19
00:00:48.076 --> 00:00:51.357
thousands of years ago may have done,
what we do in the modern day.

20
00:00:51.357 --> 00:00:53.652
How we could trace our
reference points for

21
00:00:53.652 --> 00:00:56.903
cryptography back to some of
the earliest opportunities for

22
00:00:56.903 --> 00:00:59.975
people to engage in commerce and
exchange information.

23
00:00:59.975 --> 00:01:03.503
How they did that successfully, and that
would bring that to the modern day and

24
00:01:03.503 --> 00:01:06.674
look at some of the most recent advents
in cryptography and what we do.

25
00:01:06.674 --> 00:01:10.783
Or to take a look at how we apply
cryptography to the modern world,

26
00:01:10.783 --> 00:01:15.717
what kinds of things do we do to secure
and provide for secure communications,

27
00:01:15.717 --> 00:01:18.060
things like VPNs and how we use them.

28
00:01:18.060 --> 00:01:21.672
We're gonna take a look at all
the practical, if you will,

29
00:01:21.672 --> 00:01:26.153
applications of cryptography,
wireless, secure transmissions, and

30
00:01:26.153 --> 00:01:28.408
all those kinds of technologies.

31
00:01:28.408 --> 00:01:30.640
We're also gonna take
a look at cryptanalysis,

32
00:01:30.640 --> 00:01:34.590
the way in which we actually can
break the confidentiality and

33
00:01:34.590 --> 00:01:39.420
integrity protections that cryptography
affords us the ability to be able to use

34
00:01:39.420 --> 00:01:43.380
to securely transmit and
work with our data on a daily basis.

35
00:01:43.380 --> 00:01:46.320
We're gonna be doing all of that as
soon as you come on back and join us.

36
00:01:46.320 --> 00:01:48.770
So we look forward to spending
that time with you, and hopefully,

37
00:01:48.770 --> 00:01:52.220
we'll see you as you see us going
through all those episodes here,

38
00:01:52.220 --> 00:01:55.510
talking about the EC-Council
Certified Encryption Specialist.

39
00:01:55.510 --> 00:01:59.399
Please come back and join us, and we'll be
happy to spend time with you doing that.

40
00:01:59.399 --> 00:02:01.011
>> Thank you.

41
00:02:01.011 --> 00:02:03.311
[SOUND]

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.147
Welcome back to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.147 --> 00:00:01.887
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:01.887 --> 00:00:05.924
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.924 --> 00:00:08.243
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.243 --> 00:00:11.522
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:11.522 --> 00:00:14.516
>> Welcome to your EICES series.

7
00:00:14.516 --> 00:00:16.533
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:16.533 --> 00:00:19.396
In this episode, we will be taking
a journey back through time.

9
00:00:19.396 --> 00:00:22.705
And our tour guide is going to be Mr.
Adam Gordon.

10
00:00:22.705 --> 00:00:24.990
Thank you for joining us today, Adam.

11
00:00:24.990 --> 00:00:25.540
>> Thank you.

12
00:00:25.540 --> 00:00:26.550
It's a pleasure to be here.

13
00:00:26.550 --> 00:00:27.784
Hopefully is everybody is doing well.

14
00:00:27.784 --> 00:00:30.830
We're gonna spend some time as
Cherokee was saying, really,

15
00:00:30.830 --> 00:00:34.800
I think very appropriately, talking about
time traveling a little bit, right?

16
00:00:34.800 --> 00:00:38.041
We're gonna go back and take a look,
at least in this discussion, this episode.

17
00:00:38.041 --> 00:00:41.450
Go back and take a look at the history
of cryptography a little better, right?

18
00:00:41.450 --> 00:00:46.383
And figure out what's gone before, what
we've done, kind of where we come from.

19
00:00:46.383 --> 00:00:48.775
In order to understand some
of the more interesting and

20
00:00:48.775 --> 00:00:52.057
exciting things that we're gonna be
talking about in upcoming episodes.

21
00:00:52.057 --> 00:00:56.733
As we continue to talk about,
not just how we apply encryption, but

22
00:00:56.733 --> 00:01:01.520
the different kinds of algorithms,
symmetric, asymmetric.

23
00:01:01.520 --> 00:01:02.720
Where encryption comes from.

24
00:01:02.720 --> 00:01:05.240
How we apply protections and
what we use and

25
00:01:05.240 --> 00:01:08.817
how we use it in order to
accomplish those particular goals.

26
00:01:08.817 --> 00:01:11.403
So when we think about
the history of cryptography,

27
00:01:11.403 --> 00:01:14.479
what we're really thinking about is,
and as Cherokee said.

28
00:01:14.479 --> 00:01:17.297
You're going back in time looking
at what we've done before,

29
00:01:17.297 --> 00:01:18.953
where does cryptography come from?

30
00:01:18.953 --> 00:01:23.124
When we think about the history
of cryptography we really have to

31
00:01:23.124 --> 00:01:24.987
go back thousands of years.

32
00:01:24.987 --> 00:01:27.380
And that may sound
surprising to a lot of you.

33
00:01:27.380 --> 00:01:31.918
When you think about the fact that
encryption and cryptography is really,

34
00:01:31.918 --> 00:01:33.510
at least today, anyway.

35
00:01:33.510 --> 00:01:35.967
A computer driven, kind of modern thought
process from a technology perspective.

36
00:01:35.967 --> 00:01:38.091
We use it in smartphones,
we use it in computers.

37
00:01:38.091 --> 00:01:44.583
We use it to protect bank transactions,
we use it to save card medical records.

38
00:01:44.583 --> 00:01:47.576
We use it for
most of the things we think about today.

39
00:01:47.576 --> 00:01:50.738
Generically lumped under
the concept of PII,

40
00:01:50.738 --> 00:01:54.313
personally identifiable information,
P-I-I.

41
00:01:54.313 --> 00:01:57.262
And the protection of those
kinds of pieces of data,

42
00:01:57.262 --> 00:01:59.482
those kinds of pieces of information.

43
00:01:59.482 --> 00:02:04.143
And as a result, we may think, and
indeed in some respects we would be right,

44
00:02:04.143 --> 00:02:06.390
that this is a more modern approach.

45
00:02:06.390 --> 00:02:09.230
A more modern thought
process to what we do.

46
00:02:09.230 --> 00:02:15.490
But the need to provide confidentiality,
protect and safeguard private information.

47
00:02:15.490 --> 00:02:17.750
We'll use the air quotes for
private, right?

48
00:02:17.750 --> 00:02:22.200
Whatever that may have been classified
as in the mind of person who creates it.

49
00:02:22.200 --> 00:02:27.468
The data owner over, basically
the entire recorded history of humanity.

50
00:02:27.468 --> 00:02:30.690
Going back thousands of years
has always been the case right?

51
00:02:30.690 --> 00:02:34.150
We've never really not
had a reason to somehow,

52
00:02:34.150 --> 00:02:37.800
some way think through the logic of
how we would protect something, right?

53
00:02:37.800 --> 00:02:38.821
So, if Cherokee and

54
00:02:38.821 --> 00:02:42.733
I are talking, and I'm telling her
something, let's just say off camera.

55
00:02:42.733 --> 00:02:46.500
So we're not talking to you, and
you're not hearing us right now.

56
00:02:46.500 --> 00:02:48.820
And I say, hey Cherokee, keep that secret.

57
00:02:48.820 --> 00:02:51.230
There's an implied contract there, right?

58
00:02:51.230 --> 00:02:54.210
I'm giving her,
I'm sharing some information with her.

59
00:02:54.210 --> 00:02:56.940
She's hopefully gonna take that and

60
00:02:56.940 --> 00:03:00.870
do whatever she needs to do to protect
that data, that information in some way.

61
00:03:00.870 --> 00:03:03.810
But that just may be simply her
not telling anybody, right?

62
00:03:03.810 --> 00:03:07.203
I mean, she just may simply keep
that information to herself.

63
00:03:07.203 --> 00:03:11.534
But she may also protect or
provide additional protections for

64
00:03:11.534 --> 00:03:12.929
that information.

65
00:03:12.929 --> 00:03:17.070
That involve one or more mechanisms,
or one or more tools, or one or

66
00:03:17.070 --> 00:03:18.240
more techniques.

67
00:03:18.240 --> 00:03:19.950
Or we could call those things and

68
00:03:19.950 --> 00:03:22.630
refer to them by a bunch of
different names and adjectives.

69
00:03:22.630 --> 00:03:27.590
But ultimately, she would apply some
sort of cryptographic thought process or

70
00:03:27.590 --> 00:03:28.485
protection.

71
00:03:28.485 --> 00:03:33.190
If she was worried about, and
I was worried about the integrity and

72
00:03:33.190 --> 00:03:35.720
the confidentiality of this data.

73
00:03:35.720 --> 00:03:39.291
And these are very important words
when we talk about cryptography and

74
00:03:39.291 --> 00:03:40.872
the history of cryptography.

75
00:03:40.872 --> 00:03:45.255
We mentioned them a lot as being two of
the three pillars of information security,

76
00:03:45.255 --> 00:03:46.980
the third being availability.

77
00:03:46.980 --> 00:03:50.082
We often talk about CIA,
right, or the Iron Triangle.

78
00:03:50.082 --> 00:03:51.980
You hear it for two different ways.

79
00:03:51.980 --> 00:03:56.280
But ultimately when we think about
encryption and we think about decryption.

80
00:03:56.280 --> 00:03:59.480
And we think about
the protection of information.

81
00:03:59.480 --> 00:04:03.388
We're really gonna focus our
conversations on the cryptography.

82
00:04:03.388 --> 00:04:08.420
And as a result we're gonna focus on the
confidentiality and the integrity pieces.

83
00:04:08.420 --> 00:04:11.090
Availability is part of that,
we wanna think about availability.

84
00:04:11.090 --> 00:04:16.740
But if we make the mythical Iron Triangle,
right out of, I'm off to the side here.

85
00:04:16.740 --> 00:04:19.198
If we make kind of that iron
triangle thought process.

86
00:04:19.198 --> 00:04:23.940
And at one of the three areas we put
each of the three items we talked about,

87
00:04:23.940 --> 00:04:25.420
C, I, and A.

88
00:04:25.420 --> 00:04:27.220
We wanna always be aware of all three.

89
00:04:27.220 --> 00:04:31.680
But availability, while it's very critical
to our conversation of cryptography.

90
00:04:31.680 --> 00:04:36.420
Because we wanna keep information
available for those authorized to see it,

91
00:04:36.420 --> 00:04:38.890
but keep it away from people that
are not authorized to see it.

92
00:04:38.890 --> 00:04:42.022
And we'll delve more into this thought
process at length in some of our

93
00:04:42.022 --> 00:04:43.839
future conversations on these topics.

94
00:04:43.839 --> 00:04:47.214
But we really wanna start
out our conversation here by

95
00:04:47.214 --> 00:04:51.041
focusing on the idea of, and
we're gonna define the terms.

96
00:04:51.041 --> 00:04:53.580
But focusing on the idea
of confidentiality,

97
00:04:53.580 --> 00:04:56.420
essentially providing protection for data.

98
00:04:56.420 --> 00:04:58.280
Keeping it away from bad people.

99
00:04:58.280 --> 00:04:59.880
And allowing authorized people to see it.

100
00:04:59.880 --> 00:05:03.820
So keep good data away from bad people,
is what I often tell my customers and

101
00:05:03.820 --> 00:05:05.460
students when we talk about this.

102
00:05:05.460 --> 00:05:09.762
And with regards to integrity, we want
to think about the ability to be able

103
00:05:09.762 --> 00:05:12.441
to change control and
change manage our data.

104
00:05:12.441 --> 00:05:16.184
So that data is not modified,
is not changed without our knowledge and

105
00:05:16.184 --> 00:05:16.952
our consent.

106
00:05:16.952 --> 00:05:20.462
Knowledge and consent of the owner and
probably the custodian.

107
00:05:20.462 --> 00:05:22.750
We're gonna define those terms as well.

108
00:05:22.750 --> 00:05:26.834
>> So, Adam [LAUGH] I've read in
the past that, royals used to, in order.

109
00:05:26.834 --> 00:05:29.094
You talked about about
humans keeping secrets and

110
00:05:29.094 --> 00:05:31.590
trying to keep that information secret.

111
00:05:31.590 --> 00:05:35.899
They would take their slaves and kind of
shave their scalps, tattoo a message in,

112
00:05:35.899 --> 00:05:38.409
let their hair grow out and
send them on the way.

113
00:05:38.409 --> 00:05:40.120
But when we're talking
about today's society,

114
00:05:40.120 --> 00:05:42.490
I don't think that'd be too acceptable,
right?

115
00:05:42.490 --> 00:05:43.397
>> Well, so that-
>> [LAUGH]

116
00:05:43.397 --> 00:05:44.920
>> So probably not.

117
00:05:44.920 --> 00:05:47.051
You can look up here.
There's not much left to shave.

118
00:05:47.051 --> 00:05:48.951
>> [LAUGH]
>> So potentially could do that but

119
00:05:48.951 --> 00:05:52.913
I'm kind of anti the whole shave the head,
put the tattoo on the scalp thing.

120
00:05:52.913 --> 00:05:54.303
>> [LAUGH]
>> I think that would be a little painful.

121
00:05:54.303 --> 00:05:57.944
But that's not just something that
may have been done historically.

122
00:05:57.944 --> 00:06:01.138
But that's also a plot line for
a more recent movie.

123
00:06:01.138 --> 00:06:06.048
>> If you actually take a look
at the Jackie Chan movies.

124
00:06:06.048 --> 00:06:09.556
>> [LAUGH]
>> The one where he is [INAUDIBLE] police

125
00:06:09.556 --> 00:06:14.585
guy and he's doing the whole
international police thing.

126
00:06:14.585 --> 00:06:17.379
I'm trying to think of name
of the movie now, Rush Hour.

127
00:06:17.379 --> 00:06:20.127
It's Rush Hour 2 or
Rush Hour 3, one of the two.

128
00:06:20.127 --> 00:06:21.958
Where they're dealing
with the Chinese triads.

129
00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.019
>> [LAUGH]
>> And the messenger for

130
00:06:24.019 --> 00:06:28.560
the triad with the list of triad
bosses is a woman, it turns out.

131
00:06:28.560 --> 00:06:32.499
Who has her head shaved, has the list
tattooed on the back of her head and neck,

132
00:06:32.499 --> 00:06:33.281
essentially.

133
00:06:33.281 --> 00:06:35.610
And, she normally has a wig on.

134
00:06:35.610 --> 00:06:36.750
She's a performer.

135
00:06:36.750 --> 00:06:38.590
Has a wig,
looks like she has a full head of hair.

136
00:06:38.590 --> 00:06:39.830
But, at some point, she takes it off, and

137
00:06:39.830 --> 00:06:42.390
you actually see the tattoo
on the back of her head.

138
00:06:42.390 --> 00:06:45.310
So, it's not just for
history anymore, boys and girls.

139
00:06:45.310 --> 00:06:48.710
We actually see evidence of that
in the real world, in modern day.

140
00:06:48.710 --> 00:06:50.045
All these kind of things occur, right?.

141
00:06:50.045 --> 00:06:53.840
I mean, there are and
have been for thousands of years.

142
00:06:53.840 --> 00:06:56.360
Many different ways for us to send and

143
00:06:56.360 --> 00:06:59.867
receive information
contextually on a timeline.

144
00:06:59.867 --> 00:07:02.724
When you think about
the technology of the day,

145
00:07:02.724 --> 00:07:05.790
something that was
permanent like a tattoo.

146
00:07:05.790 --> 00:07:10.692
That could be entrusted to an individual
by literally putting it on them,

147
00:07:10.692 --> 00:07:14.590
and then having them-
>> This evolution is just amazing.

148
00:07:14.590 --> 00:07:17.602
The way that we work, if you think
about it, and to where we're headed.

149
00:07:17.602 --> 00:07:21.260
>> Well, the continuing advent of
technology is always interesting to look

150
00:07:21.260 --> 00:07:23.620
at from a timeline and
from an arc perspective.

151
00:07:23.620 --> 00:07:29.120
But when you look at the limitations
of the time, something like tattooing.

152
00:07:29.120 --> 00:07:31.120
While it was permanent so
you would always carry it.

153
00:07:31.120 --> 00:07:33.812
And you couldn't screw it up because
somebody read the message and

154
00:07:33.812 --> 00:07:34.548
knew what it was.

155
00:07:34.548 --> 00:07:37.478
So long as you put it on there
the right way, it was permanently,

156
00:07:37.478 --> 00:07:40.373
indelibly marked on you and
the message would be transmitted.

157
00:07:40.373 --> 00:07:44.405
But the problem is of course,
somebody captured you, right, in theory,

158
00:07:44.405 --> 00:07:46.071
or found you as the messenger.

159
00:07:46.071 --> 00:07:47.235
They would have the message.

160
00:07:47.235 --> 00:07:49.462
Even if it was in code,
they would have the message.

161
00:07:49.462 --> 00:07:53.272
More modern means where we are
transmitting electronic bits and bytes,

162
00:07:53.272 --> 00:07:54.091
essentially.

163
00:07:54.091 --> 00:07:55.597
Little bits of data, ones and

164
00:07:55.597 --> 00:07:58.747
zeroes that go through some
sort of digital transformation.

165
00:07:58.747 --> 00:08:01.169
Or multiple rounds,
what we would call XORing,

166
00:08:01.169 --> 00:08:03.126
multiple rounds of transformations.

167
00:08:03.126 --> 00:08:07.011
And we'll talk a lot about this
whole though process At some point,

168
00:08:07.011 --> 00:08:09.544
when we go through those mechanisms today.

169
00:08:09.544 --> 00:08:12.734
It's not that much different in some
respects than what we would have

170
00:08:12.734 --> 00:08:13.510
done years ago.

171
00:08:13.510 --> 00:08:16.720
The difference is we're using different
tools and we're using different

172
00:08:16.720 --> 00:08:20.500
technologies, but the end result
is the same, the need is the same.

173
00:08:20.500 --> 00:08:21.742
Keep good data away from bad people.

174
00:08:21.742 --> 00:08:25.450
Figure out how to translate that
data into a protected package.

175
00:08:25.450 --> 00:08:30.490
And send it securely off to people that
then are gonna be able to receive it,

176
00:08:30.490 --> 00:08:32.170
decode it essentially.

177
00:08:32.170 --> 00:08:35.303
Decrypt it and understand it and
perhaps respond in kind.

178
00:08:35.303 --> 00:08:41.760
There have been, and continues to be,
ongoing conversations in many communities.

179
00:08:41.760 --> 00:08:45.726
About the efficacy and the value of
security and the ways we apply it.

180
00:08:45.726 --> 00:08:51.610
And there have been, and continue to be,
many let's say, revelations, right?

181
00:08:51.610 --> 00:08:54.654
From time to time about the impact
of the security mechanisms

182
00:08:54.654 --> 00:08:57.705
being used by governments and

episodes.description:
**Errata - Symmetric decryption is expressed mathematically as:   
P = D(k,c)  
Plaintext (P) is equal to the decryption function (D) with the key (k) and ciphertext (c) being passed as parameters to that function.

Written works such as Claude Shannon's Communication Theory of Secrecy Systems lay a mathematical foundation Cherokee and Adam reference in this show.  Adam demonstrates the mathematical expression of symmetric encryption and decryption. They also reiterate terms such as diffusion, confusion and the avalanche effect.

676

version of, what we think of now,

677

So PFX certification,
or, PFX certification,

679

PFX extension on a certificate is
just an earlier version of that.

680
00:32:22.730 --> 00:32:26.710

self sign certificates, ABCS for

681

output that way.

00:32:31.030 --> 00:32:34.840

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Adam discuss Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) and the various deployment methods. Learn the functions and roles of components such as Certificate Authorities (CAs), Registration Authorities (RAs),  Certificate Revocation Lists (CRLs) and associated protocols.

key thought processes or concepts.

21
00:01:06.210 --> 00:01:08.180
Number one, hierarchy, right, and

22

the thought process of how
do we relate through a,

23
00:01:12.490 --> 00:01:17.790
either hierarchical order, parent, child,
grandchild, and we think of it that way.

24

Or a root CA, intermediate,
and perhaps subordinate CA,

25

26

and by extension trust,

32

We're also gonna think about what

33

34

people use them, machines use them,

35

we can digitally sign,

36

do all sorts of stuff.

37

38

43
00:02:09.030 --> 00:02:10.530
And we're gonna be on the lookout for

44
00:02:10.530 --> 00:02:14.450
discussing the concept of what we call the
CRL, the certificate revocation list, so

45
00:02:14.450 --> 00:02:16.550
we're gonna take a look at that and
talk about that.

46
00:02:16.550 --> 00:02:20.890
We're also gonna bring in some of
the optional components, that may or

47
00:02:20.890 --> 00:02:23.900
may not be part of a normal
PKI implementation,

48
00:02:23.900 --> 00:02:26.800
because there are different
ways we can deploy PKI.

49
00:02:26.800 --> 00:02:32.150
A single tier, or one-level hierarchy,
essentially a certificate authority

50
00:02:32.150 --> 00:02:36.410
of one, so we're gonna talk about that as
an all-in-one kind of thought process.

51
00:02:36.410 --> 00:02:40.630
We may then see a built out hierarchy
where we have either a single or

52
00:02:40.630 --> 00:02:44.880
multiple level hierarchy with a root,
perhaps an intermediate, and

53
00:02:44.880 --> 00:02:47.650
a subordinate, or
perhaps just a root and a subordinate.

54
00:02:47.650 --> 00:02:50.490
So we're gonna look at different levels,
but we're gonna bring in some optional

55
00:02:50.490 --> 00:02:53.220
components that may or
may not normally exist.

56
00:02:53.220 --> 00:02:55.620
Especially if we do
a single level hierarchy,

57
00:02:55.620 --> 00:02:59.460
where we have just one root
CA that acts as a root CA,

58
00:02:59.460 --> 00:03:04.380
an issuing and subordinate CA,
an authenticator all in one.

59
00:03:04.380 --> 00:03:08.050
We would not see broken out separately the
role of something called a registration

60
00:03:08.050 --> 00:03:08.980
authority, and

61
00:03:08.980 --> 00:03:12.170
perhaps a validating authority
depending on how we choose to do this.

62
00:03:12.170 --> 00:03:15.560
And so we'll draw you out
a little bit on those issues and

63

those differences as we go

64
00:03:18.640 --> 00:03:21.540
And then in addition,
we're gonna take a look at and

65

that certificate revocation list,

66
00:03:26.860 --> 00:03:29.440
to validate whether or
not a certificate is legitimate.

67
00:03:29.440 --> 00:03:33.370
And we do this, historically it's
been a very person intensive or

68

69
00:03:36.890 --> 00:03:40.700

70

We do have an automation capability we can
throw in there, something known as OCSP,

71

the online certificate status protocol,
so we'll take a look at that.

72
00:03:48.420 --> 00:03:53.180
Also something known as server based
certificate validation protocol, SCVP,

73
00:03:53.180 --> 00:03:55.490
which is not as well known as OCSP.

74
00:03:55.490 --> 00:03:59.489
A lot of people don't realize that exists,
it's actually been around for

75

a while, based on an RFC standard,
RFC 5055, and we'll talk about that and

>> Okay, so we are gonna go if we could,

So we're gonna talk about certificates.

So this is what we call

And we'll see here, great labeling and

I see Alice and Bob.

00:06:45.581 --> 00:06:48.781
So the interesting thing about
this particular solution,

139
00:06:48.781 --> 00:06:51.469
as I mentioned all-in-one,

140
00:06:51.469 --> 00:06:55.191
issuing CA functionality obviously

141
00:06:55.191 --> 00:06:59.961
But because of that we are going to,
in a [COUGH] nontraditional way,

142
00:06:59.961 --> 00:07:05.233
deploy PKI inside of an infrastructure,
inside of an organization that,

143
00:07:05.233 --> 00:07:10.338
although it works, although it is

144
00:07:10.338 --> 00:07:16.197
well documented, time tested practice in

145
00:07:16.197 --> 00:07:21.770
there are some security liabilities we
have to think about with this, right.

146
00:07:21.770 --> 00:07:25.480
And we do have to be aware of the fact
that although we can do this,

147
00:07:25.480 --> 00:07:28.310
it does open us up
potentially to liability.

148
00:07:28.310 --> 00:07:32.600
Because we are allowing the root CA, and
we talked about the value of the root

149
00:07:32.600 --> 00:07:36.825
CA in our prior conversation,
our prior episode around certificates, and

150
00:07:36.825 --> 00:07:40.335
the need to establish that hierarchy,
that chain of trust, right.

151
00:07:40.335 --> 00:07:44.552
But also the cut out that the intermediate
and subordinate CAs provide so

152
00:07:44.552 --> 00:07:47.180
that you don't talk
directly to the root CA,

153
00:07:47.180 --> 00:07:50.931
potentially exposing certificates
from the root CA directly.

154
00:07:50.931 --> 00:07:54.837
And if they are compromised, allowing
us to essentially go into business for

155
00:07:54.837 --> 00:07:59.101
ourselves, right, and not only see, and
authenticate, and interact with our own

156
00:07:59.101 --> 00:08:03.271
Devices, but potentially compromise
everything that is linked to that Root CA.

157
00:08:03.271 --> 00:08:05.289
And so while we understand and

158
00:08:05.289 --> 00:08:08.610
we certainly acknowledge
that this may be done.

159
00:08:09.620 --> 00:08:11.070
I've seen this done for many students and

160
00:08:11.070 --> 00:08:14.620
customers, talked about this over
the years with many individuals.

161
00:08:14.620 --> 00:08:17.197
Talked through different
architectural thought processes, and

162
00:08:17.197 --> 00:08:20.428
this has been the desired outcome for many
of them, and I have no trouble with that.

163
00:08:20.428 --> 00:08:24.441
But I always tell my customers and my
students If you're going to go this way,

164
00:08:24.441 --> 00:08:25.984
you have to accept the risk and

165
00:08:25.984 --> 00:08:29.220
the liability associated
with this deployment model.

166
00:08:29.220 --> 00:08:31.260
And you have to not only document that.

167
00:08:31.260 --> 00:08:33.060
Good oversight, good risk management.

168
00:08:33.060 --> 00:08:33.770
Good governance.

169

00:32:23.200 --> 00:32:26.690
Because that allows us to bring together
the thought process of asymmetric

710
00:32:26.690 --> 00:32:30.880
encryption, and the thought process of
not only using asymmetric encryption but

711
00:32:30.880 --> 00:32:32.770
a handshake that will negotiate.

712
00:32:32.770 --> 00:32:37.620
And therefore establish the strongest
over protection supported between

713
00:32:37.620 --> 00:32:39.750
the two parties using
digital certificates.

714
00:32:39.750 --> 00:32:43.740
So the exchange of the public key through
the ex 5 online certificate standard.

715
00:32:43.740 --> 00:32:48.050
And then the use of that seed value, that
randomization, what we refer to as the IV,

716
00:32:48.050 --> 00:32:49.600
the initialization vector.

717
00:32:49.600 --> 00:32:52.860
That's securely transmitted, so
that nobody else knows what it is,

718
00:32:52.860 --> 00:32:55.440
to establish a secure communication
in what we call the session.

719
00:32:55.440 --> 00:32:58.198
And that's what's then ultimately
used to allow us to encrypt and

720
00:32:58.198 --> 00:32:59.650
to securely communicate.

721
00:32:59.650 --> 00:33:01.890
>> Adam if you wanted to broaden
that a little bit further and

722
00:33:01.890 --> 00:33:05.720
have additional options, that's where EAP,
it would come into play there.

723
00:33:05.720 --> 00:33:08.680
We could use EAP TLS if we had other
mechanisms, like you mentioned,

724
00:33:08.680 --> 00:33:10.900
like that RSA token or
something like that.

725
00:33:10.900 --> 00:33:15.230
>> So if we wanted to add additional or
different layers of authentication,

726
00:33:15.230 --> 00:33:17.320
we could implement them through EAP.

727
00:33:17.320 --> 00:33:21.770
As I mentioned, TLS is actually
implemented as EAP with TLS,

728
00:33:21.770 --> 00:33:23.450
as one possible thought process.

729
00:33:23.450 --> 00:33:26.610
So we do see that being used,
or potentially being used.

730
00:33:26.610 --> 00:33:28.820
So there are other ways EAP can
be brought to bear and used.

731
00:33:28.820 --> 00:33:31.868
It's not just with TLS,
as I said, it's with smart cards.

732
00:33:31.868 --> 00:33:34.793
But EAP with TLS is actually
how we use smart cards,

733
00:33:34.793 --> 00:33:37.430
that's the actual mechanism we use for
smart cards.

734
00:33:37.430 --> 00:33:40.610
Because that's specific to
the digital certificate exchange,

735
00:33:40.610 --> 00:33:42.430
which is what typically
smart cards are used for.

736
00:33:42.430 --> 00:33:45.920
They gonna have your certificate or your
keys embedded in them and that's how we

737
00:33:45.920 --> 00:33:49.230
translate the certificate, and exchange
them through the use of VAP or TLS.

738
00:33:49.230 --> 00:33:52.080
That's exactly how we would do it,
and least in that one case, anyway,

739
00:33:52.080 --> 00:33:53.340
that's what we would do.

740
00:33:53.340 --> 00:33:54.550
Absolutely correct.

741
00:33:54.550 --> 00:33:55.880
>> What's next on our list here?

742
00:33:55.880 --> 00:33:57.730
>> Well,
if you're gonna let me go over time,

743

we could talk about all
sorts of cool VPN stuff.

744

>> [LAUGH] Okay.

745
00:34:00.060 --> 00:34:00.940
>> But if you're not,

746
00:34:00.940 --> 00:34:03.100
then you're gonna wait for
me to talk about that on the next episode.

747
00:34:03.100 --> 00:34:04.840
>> You're gonna make me be
the Debbie Downer here.

748
00:34:04.840 --> 00:34:05.590
That's all right.

749
00:34:05.590 --> 00:34:07.100
>> No, no.
I'm just simply pointing out that-

750
00:34:07.100 --> 00:34:08.090
>> We are out of time.

751
00:34:08.090 --> 00:34:09.180
>> We are out of time.

752
00:34:09.180 --> 00:34:12.101
And while we always wanna keep going and
talk to you about all the cool stuff,

753
00:34:12.101 --> 00:34:13.325
we don't wanna get yelled at.

754
00:34:13.325 --> 00:34:17.100
[LAUGH] So, we're gonna stop and
comeback in another episode.

755
00:34:17.100 --> 00:34:19.462
But in that upcoming episode, just so
you know, we're gonna talk about VPN, so

756
00:34:19.462 --> 00:34:21.252
that's gonna one of the [CROSSTALK]
things or stuff to get to.

757
00:34:21.252 --> 00:34:23.040
>> Perfect.

758
00:34:23.040 --> 00:34:25.987
>> We're gonna talk about EFS, the
Encrypting File System in BitLocker, so

759
00:34:25.987 --> 00:34:27.170
we'll talk a bit about that.

760
00:34:27.170 --> 00:34:32.370
We're also probably gonna talk
about the NSA Crypto Suite.

761
00:34:32.370 --> 00:34:36.590
Suite A and Suite B and
how the algorithms were graded by NSA.

762
00:34:36.590 --> 00:34:39.100
And how we are actually able to use
them and consume them publicly.

763
00:34:39.100 --> 00:34:40.640
We'll give you a little insights and
all that,

764
00:34:40.640 --> 00:34:42.375
that will be in the upcoming episode.

765
00:34:42.375 --> 00:34:42.975
All right.
>> Okay.

766
00:34:42.975 --> 00:34:46.025
>> And you don't have to have your
top secret clearance for that either,

767
00:34:46.025 --> 00:34:48.115
we're just gonna go ahead and
continue on here.

768
00:34:48.115 --> 00:34:50.465
So, stay tuned,
we're gonna sign off for this show.

769
00:34:50.465 --> 00:34:52.155
Remember I'm Cherokee Boose.

770

>> I'm Adam Gordon.

WEBVTT

1

2
00:00:01.428 --> 00:00:06.383

3

5

6

7

a previous episode, I should say now.

8

Where we're continuing to look
at applications of cryptography.

9
00:00:23.190 --> 00:00:25.500
With us today,
we have Mr Adam Gordon in studios.

10

11

12

13

14
00:00:31.588 --> 00:00:32.730

15
00:00:32.730 --> 00:00:33.490

16
00:00:33.490 --> 00:00:36.030
So I am here, you are here, hopefully.

17

Hopefully we are here together.

18
00:00:37.360 --> 00:00:40.170
And Cherokee is here, which means we
gonna have a very fun, exciting and

19

20

I have a feeling about VPNs.

21
00:00:42.470 --> 00:00:46.928
So let's talk about VPN, some other
things, let's talk about VPNs, EFS,

22
00:00:46.928 --> 00:00:50.427
Bitlocker as I mentioned in
the outro of our prior episodes,

23
00:00:50.427 --> 00:00:52.569
if you haven't seen that by the way.

24
00:00:52.569 --> 00:00:57.261
We've talked a lot about the practical
applications of cryptography

25
00:00:57.261 --> 00:01:02.031
from various levels and various points,
we've gone deeply into PKI,

26
00:01:02.031 --> 00:01:07.758
deeply into certificates, talked about
digital signatures, talked about the ways

27
00:01:07.758 --> 00:01:13.355
in which our certificates are structured,
talked about certificate life cycle.

28
00:01:13.355 --> 00:01:18.441
We've spoken about how wireless
encryption is carried out,

29
00:01:18.441 --> 00:01:25.103
different standards that we use there,
WEP, WPA, WPA2, WPA2 Enterprise.

30
00:01:25.103 --> 00:01:29.592
We talked about a lot of different things
that are building blocks that continue

31
00:01:29.592 --> 00:01:34.283
to expand our knowledge and our thought
processes around how we apply cryptography

32

in the real world,

33

I'm not saying you have to
necessarily go back and

34

watch them in order, but
just indicating that

35
00:01:41.660 --> 00:01:45.220
we're picking up on themes that we've
talked about in those other episodes here.

36
00:01:45.220 --> 00:01:47.580
And so we just wanna make sure you're
comfortable with where all that knowledge

37
00:01:47.580 --> 00:01:48.240
is coming from.

38
00:01:48.240 --> 00:01:50.940
And if you're not sure about something,
always invite you to go back and

39
00:01:50.940 --> 00:01:51.810
take a look.

40
00:01:51.810 --> 00:01:54.460
Come on back when you've seen it and
pick us back up here,

41
00:01:54.460 --> 00:01:57.160
and we'll be happy to continue
this conversation with you.

42
00:01:57.160 --> 00:01:58.180
So let's talk about VPNs,
>> Sure.

43
00:01:58.180 --> 00:01:59.040
>> And what they are.

44
00:01:59.040 --> 00:02:04.010
So if I asked you to give us a high level
definition of what a VPN is, what would

45
00:02:04.010 --> 00:02:08.610
you tell our kind folk in studio
audience land out there for IT Pro TV?

46
00:02:08.610 --> 00:02:11.990
How would we describe what a VPN
is to somebody if they asked us?

47
00:02:11.990 --> 00:02:13.060
What would you tell them?

48
00:02:13.060 --> 00:02:16.020
>> All right, I would try to work
the word tunneling in there,

49
00:02:16.020 --> 00:02:19.250
because they probably read it or heard
it or seen it in some context already.

50
00:02:19.250 --> 00:02:25.693
So tunneling is kind of establishing
an end to end communication.

51
00:02:25.693 --> 00:02:30.789
VPN's are a more modern approach
to having a private connection,

52
00:02:30.789 --> 00:02:35.440
whether it be from site to host,
host to host, site to site.

53
00:02:35.440 --> 00:02:39.860
But it's a way that I can communicate
over a public network privately.

54
00:02:39.860 --> 00:02:41.230
>> Okay, so like that.

55
00:02:41.230 --> 00:02:44.010
The way we can communicate over
a public network privately.

56
00:02:44.010 --> 00:02:45.890
>> Yes.
>> It's a great wat of thinking about VPN.

57
00:02:45.890 --> 00:02:48.950
We bring tunneling in there and
we're gonna talk about tunneling here,

58
00:02:48.950 --> 00:02:51.800
with some of the protocols
that work with VPNs.

59
00:02:51.800 --> 00:02:56.050
But the idea of being able to extend that
private network through a public network.

60
00:02:56.050 --> 00:03:00.610
But to do so securely through a tunnel
is the mechanism, the thought process,

61
00:03:00.610 --> 00:03:05.190
the underlying reasons why VPNs are so
important to us, and have been for many,

62
00:03:05.190 --> 00:03:06.370
many years now.

63
00:03:06.370 --> 00:03:10.775
Because we need that capability to be able
to reach into our private networks from

64
00:03:10.775 --> 00:03:15.310
outside and access data, content,
material, information, variety of forms in

65
00:03:15.310 --> 00:03:19.108
a way that will not expose it to people
that are not supposed to see it.

66
00:03:19.108 --> 00:03:23.540
So doing that over the public network is
exactly what VPNs are designed to do.

67
00:03:23.540 --> 00:03:27.080
We do have common protocols, all of them
will revolve around using tunneling in

68
00:03:27.080 --> 00:03:30.500
some way, as you described,
that we could use to set up VPNs.

69
00:03:30.500 --> 00:03:33.960
We often think about things, like, PPTP,
Point-to-Point Tunneling Protocol,

70
00:03:33.960 --> 00:03:38.030
an oldie, but a goodie, although we
don't tend to use it as much anymore.

71
00:03:38.030 --> 00:03:40.905
We think about L2TP,
Layer 2 Tunneling Protocol.

72
00:03:40.905 --> 00:03:43.603
We've got an interesting little
conversation, we'll have about that.

73
00:03:43.603 --> 00:03:44.739
Not as interesting and

74
00:03:44.739 --> 00:03:48.505
obvious as some people make it out to
be because the interesting thing about

75
00:03:48.505 --> 00:03:51.700
L2TP is that it actually does
nothing to encrypt our traffic.

76
00:03:51.700 --> 00:03:53.890
That is only an authentication.

77
00:03:53.890 --> 00:03:55.370
I think it is nothing more than that.

78
00:03:55.370 --> 00:04:00.220
People don't often realize that and
when we talk about L2TP, we have to talk

79
00:04:00.220 --> 00:04:04.050
about it in respect to IPsec and
you'll often hear almost that exception.

80
00:04:04.050 --> 00:04:04.850
You always hear.

81
00:04:04.850 --> 00:04:09.202
People say I'm using an L2TP with or
plus, or someway indicating that they're

82
00:04:09.202 --> 00:04:12.082
adding IPsec to the mix VPN
because we can't really,

83
00:04:12.082 --> 00:04:15.282
although technically we could
do an L2TP tunnel for VPN and

84
00:04:15.282 --> 00:04:19.634
we would certainly be able to establish
a communication channel it would miss and

85
00:04:19.634 --> 00:04:23.540
be lacking the one fundamental thing
that Cherokee described you need.

86
00:04:23.540 --> 00:04:26.297
>> Yeah you could create it but
that's kind of the point, right?

87
00:04:26.297 --> 00:04:29.370
Well,-
>> Most people wanna have that encryption

88
00:04:29.370 --> 00:04:31.261
with their-
>> You need not just the authentication,

89
00:04:31.261 --> 00:04:32.293
you need the encryption.

90
00:04:32.293 --> 00:04:32.997
>> Yeah.
>> So,

91
00:04:32.997 --> 00:04:37.180
the whole idea of a VPN would be
lost if we just did L2TP by itself.

92
00:04:37.180 --> 00:04:42.370
So, we break out IPSec separately and
say, and by the way, we also use IPSec.

93
00:04:42.370 --> 00:04:45.510
But really, you never see L2TP
implemented without IPsec.

94
00:04:45.510 --> 00:04:48.478
So, it's really an L2TP plus IPsec VPN.

95
00:04:48.478 --> 00:04:50.750
So just wanna think about that and
be aware of that.

96
00:04:50.750 --> 00:04:53.690
So these are the common tunneling
protocols that are used.

97
00:04:53.690 --> 00:04:57.275
So let's talk about PPTP and where it
comes from historically for a minute.

98
00:04:57.275 --> 00:05:03.100
Point-to-Point-Tunneling Protocol
works at layer 2 as L2TP does as well.

99
00:05:03.100 --> 00:05:06.440
Layer 2 of the OSI model,
the data link layer.

100
00:05:06.440 --> 00:05:08.760
They both work at layer
2 of the OSI model.

101
00:05:08.760 --> 00:05:12.640
Take a slightly different approach to how
they populate and therefore how they work.

102
00:05:12.640 --> 00:05:14.970
But, both work at layer 2.

103
00:05:14.970 --> 00:05:18.330
PPTP provides both authentication and
encryption capabilities.

104
00:05:18.330 --> 00:05:22.580
So, it does natively encrypt,
unlike L2TP, which does not.

105
00:05:22.580 --> 00:05:25.623
We use EAP,
our friend from our last episode,

106
00:05:25.623 --> 00:05:29.685
Extensible Authentication Protocol
and/or CHAP to provide

107
00:05:29.685 --> 00:05:31.723
the authentication for PPTP.

108
00:05:31.723 --> 00:05:35.300
So we use some of the prior authentication
protocols we've spoken about.

109
00:05:35.300 --> 00:05:39.530
And on the encryption side or
the confidentiality side of PPTP,

110
00:05:39.530 --> 00:05:43.700
we use MPPE,
Microsoft Point to Point Encryption.

111
00:05:43.700 --> 00:05:49.550
And MPPE is actually a Microsoft
specific implementation of DES.

112
00:05:49.550 --> 00:05:51.150
So they actually take DES and

113
00:05:51.150 --> 00:05:54.510
they actually had wizards at Microsoft,
years ago.

114
00:05:54.510 --> 00:05:58.820
Took DES, modified it, implemented
it in a slightly different guise and

115
00:05:58.820 --> 00:06:00.430
called it MPPE.

116
00:06:00.430 --> 00:06:03.470
And we only, only, only, only,
very important to stress,

117
00:06:03.470 --> 00:06:06.860
only can use PPTP over
standard IP network.

118
00:06:06.860 --> 00:06:10.280
Meaning standard traditional
ethernet network, no problem.

119
00:06:10.280 --> 00:06:13.620
But unlike L2TP which is more flexible and

120
00:06:13.620 --> 00:06:17.850
affords us additional connection
network topology capabilities.

121
00:06:17.850 --> 00:06:19.170
I got it right this time, right?

122
00:06:19.170 --> 00:06:20.900
So X.25, ATM, frame,

123
00:06:20.900 --> 00:06:25.650
you may or may not be familiar with
these particular network types.

124
00:06:25.650 --> 00:06:29.445
But if you're not, I'm sure we have some
interesting conversations that we can have

125
00:06:29.445 --> 00:06:31.087
through Network+, for instance.

126
00:06:31.087 --> 00:06:35.310
Of course we'll look at some of
the episodes and shows we have there.

127
00:06:35.310 --> 00:06:39.840
Probably any of the introductory Cisco
material we have at ITPRO.TV in our

128
00:06:39.840 --> 00:06:44.810
library around CCENT and or CCNA would
provide a good overview of Frame,

129
00:06:44.810 --> 00:06:48.300
ATM and
all sorts of other stuff including X25.

130
00:06:48.300 --> 00:06:52.240
X25 is kind of an oldy used on
telepathy systems more often than not.

131
00:06:52.240 --> 00:06:56.189
But we certainly do see other network
connectivity types needed and

132
00:06:56.189 --> 00:07:00.076
PPTP would not be supported there,
only on standard IP networks.

133
00:07:00.076 --> 00:07:03.600
L2TP can be used to create VPNs
across these other network types, so

134
00:07:03.600 --> 00:07:07.381
it is more flexible which kind of
interesting so we wanna be aware of that.

135
00:07:07.381 --> 00:07:09.868
But L2TP, as I talked about,
is actually, and

136
00:07:09.868 --> 00:07:12.900
there's another thing
people don't often know.

137
00:07:12.900 --> 00:07:18.520
L2TP is actually PPTP combined with
a Cisco proprietary protocol called L2F,,

138
00:07:18.520 --> 00:07:22.790
Layer 2 Forwarding, which is why we firmly
anchor it at Layer 2 of the OSI model.

139
00:07:22.790 --> 00:07:27.700
And so, we combine L2F and PPTP together,
and as a result we get what's commonly now

140
00:07:27.700 --> 00:07:33.030
referred to as L2TP, but without
encryption capabilities without IPsec.

141
00:07:33.030 --> 00:07:34.270
And so we often, as we said,

142
00:07:34.270 --> 00:07:38.640
we'll refer to L2TP with IPsec
when we talk about VPNs.

143
00:07:38.640 --> 00:07:43.720
Layer 2 of the OSI model, we combine
PPTP and Cisco's L2F protocol together.

144
00:07:43.720 --> 00:07:48.446
We do get additional methods that
are available to us for authentication.

145
00:07:48.446 --> 00:07:53.694
Remember PPTP uses either EAP,
Extensible Authentication Protocol, and

146
00:07:53.694 --> 00:08:00.011
or CHAP, not MS-CHAP, not Microsoft CHAP,
but CHAP Generically to do authentication.

147
00:08:00.011 --> 00:08:04.690
We get those two mechanisms without TTP,
but we also get others.

148
00:08:04.690 --> 00:08:07.810
We get in addition to that we also get,

149
00:08:07.810 --> 00:08:11.660
what do we get, we get PAP,
SPAP and we get MS-CHAP.

150
00:08:11.660 --> 00:08:16.770
So we actually do bring in
MS-CHAP Microsoft specific CHAP with L2TP.

151
00:08:16.770 --> 00:08:20.470
So we're blending Microsoft, Sysco,
and all this stuff in a blender, and

152
00:08:20.470 --> 00:08:23.580
we pour it out, and
you get L2TP without IPsec.

153
00:08:23.580 --> 00:08:25.090
And when we add IPsec,

154
00:08:25.090 --> 00:08:28.020
we get the additional capability
to be able to then bring in

155
00:08:28.020 --> 00:08:32.980
the encryption mechanisms required to
provide confidentiality for that VPN.

156
00:08:32.980 --> 00:08:36.870
So L2TP VPNs with IPsec
add that capability.

157
00:08:36.870 --> 00:08:41.420
And then we have a fourth type of VPN or
if you think of L2TP with IPsec together,

158
00:08:41.420 --> 00:08:42.405
would be a third type.

episodes.description: In this show Cherokee and Adam begin covering Virtual Private Networks (VPNs). They also explain the underpinning protocols that provide tunneling and encryption. 00:01:07.223 --> 00:01:11.777

38
00:01:54.971 --> 00:01:57.563

41

the bad actor, the threat source, whatever

00:02:10.739 --> 00:02:15.729

00:02:15.729 --> 00:02:20.475

00:02:20.475 --> 00:02:22.980
We would allow them to see
the cypher text in theory, right?

00:02:22.980 --> 00:02:24.190
That wouldn't be a problem.

46
00:02:24.190 --> 00:02:27.141

00:02:27.141 --> 00:02:29.011

00:02:35.187 --> 00:02:38.556

00:02:38.556 --> 00:02:41.890

53
00:02:41.890 --> 00:02:44.840
Remember we may use the sender's

54
00:02:44.840 --> 00:02:48.568

55
00:02:48.568 --> 00:02:53.315
So for instance, if an attacker,
perhaps named Jessica, for instance.

56
00:02:53.315 --> 00:02:54.893
Let's just say that's our attacker.

57
00:02:54.893 --> 00:02:59.548
If Jessica was gonna go out and
try to potentially grab information about

58
00:02:59.548 --> 00:03:02.686
a secure communication
between Cherokee and I.

59
00:03:02.686 --> 00:03:08.079
And Jessica knew that the both
of us were the parties involved,

60
00:03:08.079 --> 00:03:13.901
she may be able to go out and
find Cherokee's and/or my public key.

61
00:03:13.901 --> 00:03:17.280
She may in theory as an attacker
be able to get the public key.

62
00:03:17.280 --> 00:03:20.069
But Kerckhoff says keep
that private key secure.

63
00:03:20.069 --> 00:03:24.964
And if we do that then it's gonna be a lot
less likely that an attacker can gain

64
00:03:24.964 --> 00:03:28.712
enough information that they
can actually figure out what

65
00:03:28.712 --> 00:03:32.410

00:03:32.410 --> 00:03:33.197

00:03:38.786 --> 00:03:40.265

00:03:42.317 --> 00:03:45.815

75
00:03:45.815 --> 00:03:46.733
Well, for herself anyway, right?

76
00:03:46.733 --> 00:03:50.273
>> [LAUGH]

77
00:03:50.273 --> 00:03:53.442
no matter what happens,
